Stef,

I donated $5 from PayPal this past weekend.  Thanks for all the great work. 
 FYI:  These "Truth about" episodes are interesting, but almost like 
muck-raking in some regards.  I only made it five minutes into this video 
and quit when the emphasis shifted to MLK's plagiarism.  Does it not seem a 
bit Ellsworth-Toohey-like to produce these episodes denigrating great 
historical leaders in order to make them seem "more human" to us aspiring 
commoners?  I wonder if it might be a greater service to humanity to allow 
these characters some grace, and overlook their relatively petty flaws in 
respect of their greater feats of leadership and perseverance.  Criticizing 
a civil rights leader for plagiarism while downplaying the organized crime 
machine of slavery, extortion and racketeering he came from seems almost 
unethical.  Where in the great book of morality does it say one must cite 
the original author of every sentence written or spoken in deference to the 
original authorship?  I understand university papers aren't supposed to be 
plagiarized, but the matter in contention is one of passages, not pages and 
pages.  If BU's professor's let it slide, it's not exactly Dr King's fault 
nobody held him to a higher standard in the awarding of his Doctorate.  I 
didn't hear you denigrate the Dr's professors at BU.  Is that because they 
weren't prominent black civil rights leaders?  

I'd rather learn more about the extraordinary feats of accomplishment of 
great characters in history than spend time studying trivial petty 
shortcomings.  Thanks for the info.﻿

I think you misunderstand Dr. King's intentions. It's not that he thought 
the government was the perfect solution for inequality, but at that time 
black people were literally being slaughtered by whites, and that needed to 
stop ASAP. 

It would be like saying "that woman shouldn't ask for the police to help 
her while she's being raped, because the police themselves are violent." 
The best course of action is to get the police to stop her attacker. Then 
once the trauma is over she can begin to look at whether or not the police 
are the best solution going forward.

You say "if you want to be the moral instructor for mankind, you might want 
to think about keeping your vows to God and your wife."
Saying that Martin Luther King wanted to be a "moral instructor for 
mankind" is incredibly cheap. He never claimed to be a messiah. All he 
wanted was for blacks to be seen as human beings for once. 
You'd have a point if he was preaching moral purity, but he wasn't. He was 
saying that black people shouldn't be treated like animals anymore. That's 
something that everyone should agree on, independent of whether or not he 
was faithful to his wife, and independant of his politics.

You're politicizing and inflating the importance of the details in his 
life, which ultimately distracts from the idea he died for which was simply 
that human beings should stop being treated as sub-humans if they are born 
black. That idea has nothing to do with communism, big government, the 
right or the left. Bringing your own personal politics into it is 
irresponsible, self-serving, and cheap.﻿

"Another means of silently lessening the inequality of property is to 
exempt all from taxation below a certain point, and to tax the higher

We live in a democracy, so State racism indicates racist behavior among the 
majority of individual voting citizens.  A neat distinction between “The 
State” and the citizenry is not possible.

King was not an anarchist, or even a libertarian; he did believe in the 
legitimacy of government, and therefore, in some types of sanctioned force. 
But he also believed in nonviolent resistance to the government’s *abuses* 
of its monopoly on force. That’s consistent with desiring reparations and 
concessions, and it is exceptionally, though not utterly, nonviolent. 
Believing in Rule of Law is not widely considered advocacy of violence. 
You’re splitting some fine hairs.

Violence is hard to eradicate. Government monopoly on violence represents a 
considered attempt to put limitations on violence, which, thus far, is the 
best we've been able to do. I think it naive to believe that eliminating 
the State would eliminate violence.

People who never owned slaves benefit from the profits of slavery, while 
people who never were slaves suffer from the economic and social tolls of 
slavery. A person’s relationship to slavery does not have to be immediate 
to be very real; reparations are one avenue for redistributing stolen and 
hoarded wealth that has passed, through inheritance, to those whose 
forebears stole it. Might be the best avenue, might not be, but it’s far 
from ridiculous. We have been redistributing wealth by force, in the form 
of taxes, since the passage of the United States Constitution. Of course we 
cannot entirely resolve slavery, since we cannot turn time back to undo it, 
but that does not mean we should make no attempt at tilting the balance of 
circumstances towards justice. 

The reality that King was not a consistently admirable father and husband 
does not negate the important contributions he made to the progress of 
civil rights in his country. That he was not faithful to his wife, that he 
plagiarized, these are widely known facts. Despite these serious flaws, we 
can still acknowledge his positive influence and his remarkable 
achievements. Thomas Jefferson was no saint, either.

Saying that people must be considered *more important* than machines is not 
equivalent to calling for a ban on all computers and farm machines. It is 
discouraging that you label King economically illiterate and an idiot 
simply because he held different economic beliefs than yours. Many highly 
educated and intelligent economists are Social Democrats.
 
The question about paying water bills in a world that is two-thirds water 
can be taken rhetorically rather than literally. King talks about 
restructuring society so that all people have access to essential common 
goods. Many smart people consider access to water a human right and are 
concerned about ownership of the world’s potable water by private 
corporations or others who can deny access to something folks will die for 
lacking. It is true, of course, that the two watery thirds of the world do 
not provide endless drops to drink. That’s not the point.

Your argument that nonviolent protests of racism, at great personal risk to 
the participants, represented nothing more than thinly-veiled power grabs 
strikes me as witheringly dismissive. It rings of the often repeated claim 
that America’s Civil War was primarily about states’ rights, rather than 
about slavery, another reductive theory.﻿

scrutinized and people should be aware of their flaws I think you are wrong 
on a few accounts with MLK.  First you are projecting your current 
knowledge of the government and the world on to MLK. It is wrong to assume 
that MLK knew exactly what you knew especially since he lived in a time 
where information was not so easily obtainable as it is today. To claim 
that MLK wanted the government to get more powerful and make things worse 
is assuming his knowledge of how the government works is at the same level 
as your own.  It is most likely that he fully believed that what he was 
doing would help bring an end to racism and bring equality to the country.  
As a supporter of communist MLK most likely fully believed the biased 
doctrine he was fed and thought that it would help create his views of 
equality.  Finally you argument that because he knew violence would occur 
from his protests he supported violence is incorrect.  While he definitely 
known the outcome of sit ins and marches he is not responsible for other 
peoples violent actions.  If I told you to fuck off and you hit me in the 
face would you blame me for the assault because I insulted you?  I think 
not.  His protests were a way of not only showing the racism in the system, 
but how the government's solution of violence is wrong.  The police are the 
ones that broke US and moral laws by using excessive force, murdering, and 
killing peaceful protesters.(I know protests were not always this one 
sided, but it was MLK's intentions that they would be)  Most if not all of 
the protesters also knew the risks and still volunteered.  As far as I know 
MLK never claimed that protesters would be safe and actually led them to 
believe they would be attacked and imprisoned.  Thus since protesters 
consented and knew the risks he was not responsible for their harm or the 
violence done to them.

Now I must agree that you should call MLK was ignorant(he probably did not 
think he was), and a hypocrite many times over.  I can agree that his ideas 
on how to solve racism and inequality were fundamentally incorrect, but I 
think it is very arrogant for to assume that MLK meant malice with his 
political actions.  If there is proof of this then I will retract my 
statement, but I think it is unlikely.  If he had lived longer maybe he 
would have apologized for his mistakes.  Maybe he really was just kind of a 
dick and knew exactly what he was doing.  For better or for worse we will 
never know.

I would like to finish by saying intentions do mean a lot.  Over my 27 
years on this planet I have been a Democrat, Communist, Liberal, 
Republican, Libertarian, and finally an anarchist.  Even though I have held 
almost every point of view my end goals has always been the same.  I have 
always been interested in whatever system would lead to the least poverty, 
death, and would lead to the highest advancement for humans.  People can be 
lead astray by false information, but that does not necessarily make them 
bad people unless they break their own moral code.  Even though it seems 
you think he meant malice with his actions I doubt he did.  I think his

mistakes to make ourselves better people.﻿

I don't think YOU understand what plagiarism is. The simple definition of 
plagiarism "the practice of taking someone else's work or ideas and passing 
them off as one's own." So, repeating IDEAS is plagiarism. Stefan is 
plagiarizing just as much as MLK for borrowing the idea of his "I have a 
dream speech" from Archibald Carey, Jr

I don't think you understand what plagiarism means. It is not the same as 
hearing an argument and thinking it is true and then integrating that into 
one's reasoning. If I say 1 + 1 = 2, if I say a square circle cannot exist, 
if I say any argument I've learned and not come up with on my own, am I 
committing plagiarism? No.

Plagiarism is two things. First, it is a person reproducing the specific 
implementation of an argument for some idea created by someone else. It 
isn't repeating the idea, it is reusing the specific argument someone else 
made that describes the idea. Secondly, it is doing that while claiming 
that the specific argument copied is in fact one's own.

So your claim fails on both properties. Stefan does not copy the 
implementation of an argument, he makes his own. Where he does quote 
others, he usually makes it clear he is quoting someone unless its like 
some well known 2 or 3 word quote.

Lastly, trying to poison the well by tossing a 'pew, over your heads it 
goes' line is such an obvious attempt to hide from reasoning that it just 
looks silly. Don't first present a case like a reasonable person then 
contradict your behavior by acting so ridiculously. If you care about 
reasoning, be consistent and stick with it. Don't fall into these mean 
attacks.

Stefan, I got a lot of respect for your views and have found your videos 
interesting. Two people I have always had a lot of respect for (based on 
what I knew of them) was Ghandi and MLK. While your video on Ghandi was 
very eye opening and radically changed how I viewed him, I find this video 
less so and would even go as far as to say that you are being quite unfair 
on MLK here. Like with Ghandi, you have pointed out some definitive truths, 
but while you successfully exposed serious flaws with Ghandi as a human 
being including cruel and racist traits, with MLK you have made too many 
leaps and assumptions regarding his intent, ideas and ideals. I also think 
you have focused too much on the less relevant aspects, like his sexual 
activities or his ties to communists (I also disagree that communist should 
be equated to Al Qaeda, unless you refer to how they are regarded by the 
mainstream populace). Like you, I detest affirmative action and racial 
quotas but am not entirely convinced that MLK was pushing for the these 
things. Aside from the quotes you mentioned, I find little evidence to 
suggest that he supported the things you said, particularly the government 
enforcement you mentioned (which I feel is a good example of you making a 
big leap regarding MLK's intentions and ideals). Maybe I am showing 
ignorance and maybe I am guilty of refusing to let go of my reverence for 
MLK as quickly as I did with Ghandi, but I don't think you have given MLK 
enough credit for where he was right and perhaps have stretched things a 
bit when pointing out his wrongs. That's not to say that you didn't open my 
eyes on many faults of his character and made many pertinent points, and of 
course I understand the value in seeing the full rounded truth of his 
humanity. While I understand that MLK was far from a perfect human being, I 
still feel respect is due to a man who spoke for more truth and justice 
than most from this time and place. Just as I don't agree with everything 
you say, but respect much of what you stand for, I feel MLK deserves to be 
credited with more than plagiarism and adultery. Maybe my understanding of 
him, his words and his actions is incomplete or skewed but to me he still 
represents a man with wisdom to share and true desire for equality﻿

I get what you are saying. Just to clarify my comments regarding communism 
is that it was, back in MLK's day, demonised by the media to excessive

who support various socialist or communist ideologies that are good 
hearted and while they may be misguided in this belief they are certainly 
not evil. I don't agree with communism but many people who have socialist

equality and community. My issue with Stefan's indictment of MLK because of 
his links to communists is part down to the fact that I disagree that being 
friends with communists is akin to being friends with Al Queda, MLK 
denounced communism on many occasions and while media may have gone on the 
opposite direction in recent times, during MLK's era the anti communist 
propaganda was almost hysterical. But as I say, I am not a fan of 
communism, just don't think equating it to Al Queda is rational.

My personal issue with both communism and capitalism is that neither have 
truly manifested themselves. The virtues of capitalism is the freedom the 
free market is supposed to promote while the virtues of communism is based 
on the ideals of equality and collective support. The problem is we do not 
have the virtues of either systems. The modern state is a combination of 
the worst aspects of both. The cut throat competitive nature of capitalism 
with out the freedom it is supposed to provide, just as we get the 
imposition of socialist control with out the equality that system is 
supposed to promote.
Just as capitalists would argue that true capitalism hasn't actually been 
displayed, as many of the flaws of our system are related to state control, 
which isn't inherently a capitalist issue. Communism sympathisers could 
also argue that the so called communist states that have existed are not 
true embodiments of that ideology. The fact that they all were under 
dictatorships is a good example of something that actually runs counter to 
the communist ethos.

I too hate the state and agree with much of what Stefan says about the need

day, and give my anarchy over all other systems that have existed and do 
exist.
I totally agree that we should be free to chose what system we wish to be a

law ethos of prohibition against causing harm or loss to another. Any other 
law outside of that mandate is by definition fascism and even laws with in 
that ethos have the problem of how can their enforcement be funded with out 
state coercion in the form of taxes. I, like Stefan, would much rather live 
in a world where such systems were more like a charity, where funding and 
support is entirely voluntary and no imposition is put on those who wish to 
have nothing to do with such systems.

+Matthew Sands"Beast or Saint The Truth about Martin Luther King" classic 
youtube video

I don't think that is a fair assessment of what I said. I was just pointing 
out that the "facts" are not as damning as they were for Ghandi. I have 
properly changed my view of Ghandi after learning many of the things about 
him that demonstrate cruelty and perversion. I don't think the same is true 
of MLK and the facts given about him are far less damming IMO. I don't 
think he is a saint, nor did I before, and was already aware of some of the 
aspects mentioned, like his links to communism or sexual activities. But 
while Stefan revealed some real traits of cruelty and borderline pedofilia 
from Ghandi, it seems the worst he can say about MLK is that he engaged in 
sexual debauchery (with consenting adults) and was guilty of plagiarism in 
his younger days.
The communism links are not something that concerns me that much and are 
not so well established either. Do you really agree that communism is or 
was equivalent to Al Queda? Because I don't and know many good hearted 
people who have many socialist ideas. Also MLK denounced communism on many 
occasions.
While Stefan has given some quotes and actions of MLK that suggest he 
supported affirmative action he neglects to mention many quotes and actions 
that suggest that he would not, so I don't think it is unreasonable for me 
to remain unconvinced that he would support this, though I accept I may be 
wrong.
Basically, all I am saying is that there are one or two leaps made here by 
Stefan. The Ghandi video stuck to cold hard facts and demonstrated a lot of 
cause and justification for labelling Ghandi a bad man, rather than just an 
imperfect one. This MLK video shows many flaws in his character but I don't 
agree there is enough to call him a bad man.
I agree his sexual escapades make him a bad husband but I still feel he was 
a good man at the heart of things and appeared to be genuine in his fight 
for equality and freedom for all people, not just black people. I am open 
to being educated and, as I said, have genuinely changed my view of Ghandi 
based on the facts presented to me, but I am not hearing a strong enough 
case against MLK. Too much of it is based on assumptions, rather than 
facts, and too many of the facts are less relevant examples of his sexual 
weaknesses. The adultery thing for example is a bigger crime in Stefan's 
head because of his own ideals, but does it make him a bad person? Not in 
my opinion. It shows him to be weak and flawed but it is not enough to call 
him a bad person.
I think the point of Stefan's videos is to discourage hero worship and to 
remind us that even the most revered are deeply flawed. In the case of 
Ghandi he actually demonstrated enough info to show Ghandi as a bad person 
with real cruel traits and self serving hypocrisy. In the case of MLK he 
has revealed some real flaws to show that he is far from a saint, but has 
he demonstrated that MLK was a bad person? No, not even close.
One of the main reasons I respected MLK is because, despite the mainstream 
view of him being a figure for black people's rights, his words and actions 
were often about equality and justice for all. The establishment wants us 
to remember MLK as a champion for black people when the he was mostly a 
champion for poor people. Stefan is reminding us that, regardless of 
whether he is revered for fighting for black people, poor people, or all 
people, he was a very flawed human being. That is fine and I accept that, 
but he has not built a case that convinces me that MLK was a bad person.
Maybe I am wrong with my assumptions about things like affirmative action, 
maybe Stefan is wrong. My point is that much of this is assumptions rather 
than cold hard facts.
Maybe I am guilty of refusing to let go of my reverence for MLK. I am 
trying keep my mind open to such change, and did not have a problem 
changing my view on Ghandi after hearing some very damming information 
about him.
Just as we should not blindly hero worship people like MLK or Ghandi, we 
should also be careful not to be guilty of doing the same with Stefan. 
Rather than treating Stefan's words as the words of God, we should be 
prepared to challenge his view when we feel it is appropriate. I respect 
his view but the same lesson he teaches with regards to figures like MLK 
should be applied to him and we should be prepared to challenge him and his 
views, I would expect him to welcome such things.
Your brief appraisal of my comments seem quite close minded and dismissive 
and I don't expect you to even read my rather lengthy response, but I would 
be interested to hear Stefan's view on what I have said if he ever comes 
across these comments.

After watching a few of these videos, I think I'm starting to understand 
exactly what the problems is with your viewpoint. You act as if the state 
is its own entity to which people willfully relinquish their freedoms when 
they feel as though they need to be protected. You mentioned in the 
Scandinavia video that corporations are not people, but are in fact made of 
people from whom taxes are extorted in the form of the corporate tax. So, 
this would imply that a corporation is a particular amalgamation of people, 
carrying human flaws and representing those flaws proportionately; things 
such as greed, apathy, etc. However, when it comes to the state, which 
should be viewed very similarly, as a group of people with human-based 
flaws, suddenly the state becomes its own entity, as if it were a natural 
antagonist to humanity and can therefore never be viewed positively. 

My point is this. You automatically assume that any attempt to correct the 
system to which we submit is futile because the state itself is the 
problem. The state is neither inherently good or bad. It's made up of 
people, with the same moral strengths and weaknesses of people. And only by 
spreading the messages of morality can we hope to strengthen society 
morally, which will then flood over into the government.  The government is 
simply a sample of society. Is government the problem, or is our own nature 
as human beings the problem? And if that's the case, can nurture override 
nature so as to produce a better society? And would that society then mold 
a better government in the future? Those are the questions we should be 
asking. My problem with libertarian philosophy is that there's a breakdown 
of logic right at the core when antagonize the structure of a state as 
something beyond the reach of reasoning. A state is very much a human 
thing, and to address all of the problems within the state is to take a 
deep look at ourselves and recognize everything wrong with us. Government 
is a tool, and it's up to people, on the whole, what they choose to do with 
it. When the masses are unaware of this, the few who can then utilize the 
tool for their own well-being at the expense of others, hence the corporate 
socialism we see today. ﻿

States are made up of people, yes. They are a human construct, yes, but 
they also serve as a monopoly on violence in a given geographical area. The 
same cannot be said for companies in a purely capitalistic sense. In a free 
market companies would conduct themselves in ways that are non detrimental 
to their employees and customers, because if they don't, well, those people 
always have the choice to go to the competition.

In our current statist la la land, companies are state subsidized and state 
incorporated, and are just tools of the state and part of aforementioned 
monopoly on violence, hence the rampant crony "capitalism"  (or corporate 
socialism, as you put it) we see today. But such a construct only exists 
because the state exists. Its like a mutually beneficial parasite-host 
relationship that only serves to fuck over the rest of us because there's 
really no incentive not to. Such incentive would only exist in a free and 
open market which is not controlled by a violent monopoly.

You say to look inside ourselves to see the problems of the state. I call 
bullshit. Governments are staffed by power hungry individuals, many of whom 
are likely to suffer from grave personality disorders which completely 
negate their capacity for empathy. Thats just how it is. Those are the 
types of people who seek and maintain power. Just look at history. These 
people are not like you or I.

There really is no individual choice in the matter. Voting is a fraud, spun 
up by your psychotic masters to give you the ILLUSION of choice. Its all 
smoke and mirrors. Have you ever seen government shrink or de-regulate 
itself in any measurable manner when a D wins out over an R or vice versa?

that is indeed worthwhile and needs to be Embraced rather than "escaped"?
 At first, this may seem an uncomfortable notion to consider, let alone 
accept and integrate into your life but hear me out.
I mentioned in my previous comment about my volunteer services at those in 
need of support at a local hospital. I also admitted the struggle that on 
some days I face with that service. But what I didn't mention was the 
darkness I was thrusted into and have had to endure for the past 7 years as 
I watched my beloved life partner battle with the degenerative disease of 
multiple sclerosis and witness how it's effects has ravaged her from her 
once former independent, active, full of energy, life, laughter, joy, 
beauty and youth to her present state, bedridden, virtually completely 
paralyzed, practically 100%
dependent on me to make sure that all of her even most basic daily needs 
are met. But I remain by her side and will never leave her. Till death do 
us part. My love for her braces me through the darkness and the despair 
that I feel at times. It is this embracement of our circumstance that in 
part helps me do my voluntary work at the local hospital. The "darkness" 
once embraced helps me transcend. I now in each waking day and moment try 
to take nothing for granted. Fresh air....the breath of life....the taste & 
smell my food...I take it all in...including the hurt suffering and 
despair... all.
I fast, meditate & pray...I also yell, scream and hit things...I accept my 
flaws and pursue my strengths while living and doing the best I can.
There is a time for fasting...for consciously withdrawing for what we take 
for granted including our health and life itself. (old ppl our elders in 
retirement homes)...
A lot of suffering isn't consciously chosen  but often imposed on us (eg. 
loss of loved ones, grieving, abandonment, the inevitable old-age 
associated illnesses, burn victims or other victims of other accidents or 
circumstances that result in physical and/or psychological illness .) but 
we do have a choice in the way we respond to it. The commonly quoted 
Serenity Prayer reminds of that: 
"God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change,
The courage to change the things I can,
And the wisdom to know the difference."

So in those cases where we often have little choice about what happens to 
us and we can NO LONGER take for granted those things that we took for 
granted before, perhaps the "mystical" dimension enters into it through our 
ability to respond to it. We may not as the cliche goes "get to the other 
side of it" (however one wants to interpret that ) and there may be long 
periods of despair and darkness at first but perhaps (some will attest to) 
the only "way out" is by seeing a greater hope or something else that lies 
beyond....this creates the condition that brings about the proverbial 
"bigger picture" (noting that one could never see the whole picture if you 
are in the frame, so to speak). 
But I think the so called "darkness/despair" that we inevitably find 
ourselves walking in throughout different times of our lives is in fact, in 
and of itself, potentially instructive IF we are receptive to it. But of 
course even still we must be prepared to endure perhaps long and 
uncomfortable periods of angst, fear, sorrow..etc. that comes with this 
PATH of darkness...whereby all we can do is take it day by day with little 
sense of hope or even complete hopelessness. But their are many rituals or 
practices from various religions or spiritual systems from a variety of 
cultures that can help one through this path of darkness. These traditional 
and often ancient meditative and contemplative rituals/practices can help 
one embrace the "darkness" which seems at first at unnatural thing because 
most of us when faced with great grief and suffering will naturally want to 
run away with from it. Some will partake in various versions of "escapism" 
be it by self-medicating or unhealthy outlets and distractive but 
destructive behaviors or depend upon western psychotropic  meds like Prozac 
that also provide a form of denial and escapism ultimately preventing us 
from facing & embracing the instruction of the darkness. We try and teach 
our children to face their fears so that they can be stronger yet 
ironically we so often in this so called "modern society" are unwilling to 
do it as adults. The ancient mystical traditions teach that we should "go 
into the darkness" .. "eat the darkness into the pain" do not run away from 
it...one can not learn the lessons by choosing to run from it.  
Mechtild of Magdeburg,  a well noted thirteenth century woman of the 
Beguine Christian order wrote of this darkness in the following 
manner...she says: “There comes a time when both body and soul enter into 
such a vast darkness that one loses light and consciousness and knows 
nothing more of God’s intimacy. At such a time when the light in the 
lantern burns out the beauty of the lantern can no longer be seen. With 
longing and distress we are reminded of our nothingness….I am hunted, 
captured, bound, wounded so terribly that I can never be healed. God has 
wounded be close unto death." 15] Mechtild does not run from the darkness 
but stays and learns. “God replied: ‘I wish always to be your physician, 
bringing healing anointment for all your wounds. If it is I who allow you 
to be wounded so badly, do you not believe that I will heal you most 
lovingly in the very same hour?” What is it we learn in this darkness of 
soul and spirit? “From suffering I have learned this: That whoever is sore 
wounded by love will never be made whole unless he embrace the very same 
love which wounded her.”
